Subject: Re: Checkpoint issue Re: [archive-crawler] robots.txt problem
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=xSfrxGQ0lg1IDoTJz2CPs4JFlyQOUoDDBF-IFfXAwWOd

On 1/3/12 2:25 PM, I wrote:
> It looks like the last SEVERE error ("2011-12-27 13:18:50.197") due to
> filesystem problems left state that prevents further checkpoint attempts.
>
> It *might* be possible, with some custom heap surgery via the Scripting
> Console, to resolve that and thus give a new checkpoint a chance to
> succeed.
>
> This would involve looking closely at what wasn't done because of that
> SEVERE "java.io.IOException: Failed to create directory", and manually
> cleaning that up until the CheckpointService.requestCrawlCheckpoint()
> check (and subsequent steps) can proceed.
>
> At first glance, this might be simply: the
> CheckpointService.checkpointInProgress field needs to be null. Pausing
> the crawl, nulling that field, then manually requesting a checkpoint
> *might* create a viable checkpoint.

David asked me offlist for more details on how this might be done; 
here's a possible approach for public reference.

These steps should null the checkpointInProgress field via the web 
interface's Scripting Console:

� pause the crawl

� visit the 'Scripting console' (one of the links near the very bottom 
of the job status page)

� select (for purposes of this example) Groovy in the drop-down

� enter a script like the following:

checkpointService = appCtx.getBean("checkpointService")
checkpointService.checkpointInProgress = null

� hit the 'execute' button (either top or bottom)

At this point, the superficial reason that manual checkpoints were 
failing ("java.lang.IllegalStateException: Checkpoint already running") 
would be resolved, possibly allowing a subsequent attempt to succeed 
again.

I don't know if there are other lingering problems that would make an 
attempt fail even once this block is resolved. And it's even possible 
that a deep, thorough investigation could identify and fix such other 
problems *before* retrying another checkpoint, but that trying a 
checkpoint with only this fix would render the situation unfixable.

But depending on your tolerance for risk and time for investigation, 
this might enable a good checkpoint of current state.

(It might even be possible to restart periodic checkpointing, by 
rerunning the code that started it in the first place, from
CheckpointService.setupCheckpointTask, but I haven't looked closely at 
the risks of that approach.)

- Gordon
